Name: Instructions of Shuruppak
Short Description: Fatherly advice from the mythic king Shuruppak to his son Ziusudra (later known as the Sumerian Noah in the Eridu Genesis). Belonging to the genre of “edubba literature,” it was a didactic text taught in temple scribal schools—likely used to form the moral-bureaucratic elite of early Mesopotamian society.

Name: Kesh Temple Hymn
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: An early cosmological hymn praising the temple of the goddess Ninhursag in the city of Kesh. It describes the temple as the center of the universe, blessed by the gods, and foundational to divine order on earth.

Name: Plaque of Ur‑Nanshe
Short Description: A limestone relief divided into registers combining image and text. It depicts King Ur-Nanshe carrying a basket of bricks for temple construction, surrounded by his sons and attendants, and records his role as builder of temples for the gods Ningirsu and Nanshe. Short inscriptions identify him and highlight his pious deeds, projecting dynastic continuity and divine sanction.

Name: Stele of the Vultures
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: Commissioned by Eannatum, ruler of the city-state of Lagash, the stele commemorates his divinely sanctioned victory over the rival city-state of Umma in a long-standing border conflict. It is named for a vivid scene in which vultures are shown picking at the corpses of defeated enemies—a symbolic warning to rivals and a brutal testament to the totality of Lagash’s triumph.

Name: Administrative Tablets from Ebla
Short Description: A vast archive of over 17,000 clay tablets from the royal palace of Ebla (modern Syria), detailing trade, taxation, diplomacy, and ritual offerings.

Name: Tello Tablets
Short Description: Thousands of Sumerian cuneiform tablets excavated at Telloh (ancient Girsu, in the kingdom of Lagash). They record deliveries of grain, livestock, wool, and labor assignments for the cults of gods such as Ningirsu and Bau. The tablets are formulaic in style, listing quantities, dates, officials, and recipients, shedding light at the local temple–state economy.
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Royal Inscriptions of Sargon of Akkad
Short Description: Monumental inscriptions attributed to Sargon of Akkad, the founder of the world’s first regional empire—uniting over a dozen major Sumerian and Akkadian city-states under a single centralized authority. These texts exalt his conquests, divine election, and humble origins, shaping a prototype for Mesopotamian kingship. Inscribed during his reign and transmitted for centuries, they functioned as imperial propaganda and theological legitimation.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Self, Persona, Initiator, Father Archetype

Name: Temple Hymns of Enheduanna
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: Attributed to Enheduanna, the high priestess of Ur and daughter of Sargon of Akkad, this series of hymns praises the gods of major Sumerian temples. The text fuses spiritual devotion with political unification. Likely performed during temple rituals and preserved in scribal schools, the hymns became part of the Mesopotamian religious canon, symbolizing a sacred geography and an early imperial theology.

Name: The Exaltation of Inanna
Short Description: Also attributed to Enheduanna, composed during her political exile, the text exalts the goddess Inanna as supreme over the divine order and channels her wrath to vindicate Enheduanna’s position. Through divine invocation, personal trauma is mythologized into cosmic justice - a potent act of political theater.

Name: Eridu Genesis
Short Description: This Sumerian myth was inscribed on clay tablets from Nippur and others. It recounts the divine creation of humans, the founding of cities, and the granting of kingship. Ziusudra, a pious king, survives a god-sent flood by building a boat and is granted immortality. The text ritualizes kingship as a sacred trust and the flood as a divine reset of cosmic and social order.

Name: Curse of Agade
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Becoming (Process Ontology), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A retrospective theological narrative detailing the rise and fall of the Akkadian Empire. King Naram-Sin, in a moment of hubris, desecrates the temple of Enlil in Nippur. In response, the gods withdraw their favor, unleashing famine, invasion, and ruin upon Akkad.

Name: Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave
Short Description: Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave tells the story of a young warrior who falls ill during a military campaign and is left behind in the mountains. In solitude, he prays to the gods, is miraculously healed, and leaves the cave.

Name: Gudea Cylinders
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Monism (Single Principle), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: The longest surviving Sumerian inscriptions found on monumental clay cylinders, they recount Gudea’s dreams and divine instructions from Ningirsu to build the great temple Eninnu. The text describes visions, omens, and the gathering of exotic materials from distant lands, followed by the mobilization of labor, temple construction, and its dedication through elaborate rituals. The cylinders blend mythic revelation with political legitimation, portraying Gudea as the pious “shepherd” chosen by the gods, at the twilight of the Sumerian era.

Name: Bau Temple Archives
Short Description: A vast collection of cuneiform tablets written during and after the reign of Gudea. They preserve receipts, ration lists, labor assignments, and inventories connected to the cult of the goddess Bau. These administrative and legal records detail offerings of grain, sheep, and textiles, as well as the registration of workers, revealing the temple as both a spiritual and economic hub.

Name: Code of Ur-Nammu
Short Description: The earliest known legal code in history, attributed to King Ur-Nammu. The text presents law as a divine institution, granted by the moon god Nanna and administered through the king. More humane and orderly than later codes, it reflects the priestly vision of a well-regulated world restored after the chaos of empire and restarting the economy.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Initiator, Father Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Rebirth, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Literary Themes Tags: Ritual / Devotional, Political, Didactic / Ethical, Historical Reflection

Name: Gilgamesh and Agga
Short Description: A short heroic poem recounting Uruk’s resistance against Kish. When Agga, king of Kish, demands submission, Gilgamesh consults Uruk’s elders — a likely priestly-dominated council that counsels surrender — and then turns to the city’s young men, who urge resistance in the name of honor and freedom. Choosing to follow the voice of the youth, Gilgamesh defeats Agga, captures him, but releases him in mercy — affirming not only Uruk’s independence and his own legitimacy as king, but also the valor of warrior ethos over priestly caution. Likely first transmitted orally in Sumerian as part of heroic performance traditions, the tale was later copied in scribal schools and preserved on cuneiform tablets.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Wise Old Man, Initiator, Persona, Father Archetype

Name: Lament for Ur
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A poetic lament mourning the fall of Ur after the collapse of the Ur III dynasty, narrated through the voice of the city’s patron goddess Ningal. The text ritualizes the destruction of the sacred and political center of Sumer, presenting it as divine punishment. Likely recited during public rituals and preserved in scribal schools, the lament served to process collective grief, legitimize a new political order (such as the rising Isin dynasty), and reaffirm the mediating role of the priestly class in reestablishing divine favor.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Terrible Mother, Terrible Father, Wise Old Woman, Self, Initiator

Name: Lament for Sumer and Ur
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: Building on The Lament for Ur, this text expands the scope of grief to encompass the fall of all Sumerian civilization. While The Lament for Ur mourns a single city's destruction, The Lament for Sumer and Ur ritualizes the collapse of an entire sacred world, transforming political catastrophe into a myth of theological realignment.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Terrible Mother, Terrible Father, Wise Old Woman, Self, Initiator
Neumann Stages Tags: Separation from World Parents, Isolation, Death, Divine Intervention, Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Short Description: Through divine endorsement, ritual speech, and possibly the invention of writing, the text asserts Uruk’s supremacy over Aratta, transforming political ambition into a sacred mandate.

Short Description: A sequel to Enmerkar and the Lord of Aratta, in which Enmerkar asserts Uruk’s supremacy through a ritual contest of incantations. Aratta’s resistance collapses through the superior rhetorical and magical power of Enmerkar’s court.

Name: Lugalbanda and the Anzu Bird
Short Description: A sequel to Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave, this tale completes the hero’s transformation as Lugalbanda, newly recovered, encounters the divine Anzud Bird. By caring for its offspring, he earns the bird’s favor and is granted supernatural speed. His magical empowerment prepares him to rejoin Enmerkar’s campaign against Aratta, now as a sacred agent of divine will.

Name: Code of Lipit-Ishtar
Short Description: A Sumerian law code issued by King Lipit-Ishtar of Isin to reaffirm justice and divine order in a time of political transition. Commissioned in the name of the gods An and Enlil, the code presents the king as a humble servant restoring balance. Emphasizing restitution and procedural fairness, it reflects a priest-king's effort to unify society after the fall of the Ur III dynasty.

Name: The Descent of Inanna
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A mythic ritual text depicting the goddess Inanna’s descent into the underworld, where she is stripped of her power, killed by her sister Ereshkigal, and later revived through divine intervention. The tale dramatizes death, rebirth, and cosmic rebalancing, presenting Inanna as a divine figure whose suffering legitimizes transformation and the restoration of order. The narrative naturalizes the necessity of submission to divine cycles as a foundation for political stability.

Short Description: A mythic narrative celebrating the return of the warrior god Ninurta to Nippur after his victory over forces of chaos. The text catalogs his conquests and the spoils he brings to the temple of Enlil, reaffirming divine order and the supremacy of warrior kingship.

Short Description: Dumuzi, consort of Inanna, dreams of his impending capture by underworld demons. Interpreted by his sister Geshtinanna, the dream unfolds as a vision of sacrificial destiny. As Dumuzi flees and is eventually seized, the text ritualizes male death as cosmic necessity.

Name: Sumerian King List
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A mythic-historical record listing Sumerian kings and their reigns, blending divine origins, exaggerated time spans, and historical rulers into a single theological chronology. The text legitimizes dynasties, portrays kingship as divinely bestowed, and standardizes Sumer’s historical memory. The King List presents history as a sacred pattern ordained by the gods.

Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A ritual text recounting the burial and apotheosis of Gilgamesh, once the restless seeker of immortality. In death, he is granted a role as judge of the underworld, his personal struggle absorbed into the eternal cosmic order. The narrative reframes existential anguish into theological continuity.

Name: Code of Hammurabi
Metaphysical Tags: Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Dialectics (Conflict)
Short Description: A monumental law code attributed to Hammurabi of Babylon, engraved on a stele depicting the king receiving laws from the god Shamash. The code functioned as a divine-political declaration of imperial order. Created during Babylon’s expansion, it asserted Hammurabi’s legitimacy and sacralized kingship through the symbolism of law—uniting theological authority, bureaucratic control, and public ritual in a single carved monument.

Name: Dialogue between a Man and His God
Short Description: A personal lament in which a suffering man pleads with his god, uncertain of his guilt and abandoned in silence. One of the earliest expressions of existential anxiety, the text ends with divine forgiveness—likely a priestly addition—framing raw despair within restored cosmic order.

Short Description: A Mesopotamian creation and flood myth in which Atrahasis survives divine wrath through wisdom and ritual. Expanding on Eridu Genesis, the epic frames humanity as a labor force for the gods and ritual as a means of survival, embedding divine justification for inequality and social control.

Name: Epic of Gilgamesh
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: An existential epic centered on Gilgamesh, king of Uruk, whose journey through grief and mortality transforms him from a restless conqueror into a seeker of meaning. Composed and refined across centuries, the tale blends heroic myth with a deep inner reckoning—culminating not in triumph, but in the acceptance of death and the fragility of human legacy. A subversive and introspective voice in an age of imperial certainty, the Epic of Gilgamesh became a foundational text of Mesopotamian literature and one of the oldest surviving meditations on what it means to be human.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Shadow, Anima, Wise Old Man, Wise old Woman, Trickster, Initiator, Self, Persona, Terrible Mother, Mother Archetype

Name: Namtaru Incantations
Short Description: A collection of Akkadian healing incantations aimed at warding off Namtaru, a plague-bearing chthonic figure. The texts were spoken aloud during rituals to protect against illness, death, and demonic intrusion. The text reflects the priestly role as guardian of order, deploying language as a weapon against entropy.

Name: Urra = hubullu Series
Short Description: The compendium functions as a bilingual dictionary and taxonomy, systematically listing Sumerian words with their Akkadian equivalents across a wide range of semantic fields—such as animals, professions, tools, and natural materials. Produced and transmitted by temple scribes, the text reflects a priestly effort to preserve, organize, and transmit cultural knowledge through structured classification.

Name: Middle Assyrian Laws
Short Description: A brutal and highly formalized Assyrian law code prescribing punishments for offenses ranging from adultery and theft to bodily injury and sorcery. Reflecting the patriarchal and militarized values of Assyrian society, the laws enforce strict hierarchies between men and women, free and enslaved, elite and commoner.

Name: The Tukulti-Ninurta Epic
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: This imperial war epic recounts Tukulti-Ninurta's divinely sanctioned victory over Kashtiliash IV of Babylon. The text is designed to justify imperial expansion, delegitimize the Babylonian monarchy, and assert Assyria’s theological and cultural supremacy.

Name: Ludlul Bēl Nēmeqi
Short Description: A high official laments his inexplicable suffering and loss despite his devotion, only to be healed and restored by Marduk. The poem affirms divine justice through personal redemption, praising the god’s mysterious wisdom.

Name: Enuma Elish (Babylonian Creation Epic)
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Dialectics (Conflict), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A Babylonian creation epic in which the god Marduk defeats the chaos-dragon Tiamat and creates the world from her body, establishing himself as king of the gods. Likely written in Babylon and recited during the Akitu Festival, the text functioned as imperial mythmaking—sacralizing Babylon’s supremacy and warrior-kingship through cosmic narrative, framing divine violence as the foundation of divine order.

Name: Tale of the Poor Man of Nippur
Short Description: Akkadian tale, in which a poor man named Gimil-Ninurta humiliates the corrupt mayor of Nippur through wit and cunning. The story inverts traditional power hierarchies, mocking local elites and offering symbolic justice to the disenfranchised. As both comic relief and social critique, the tale may reflect growing tensions within a rigidly stratified society—and the subtle resistance of the scribal class to institutional hypocrisy.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Trickster, Persona, Shadow

Name: Diagnostic Handbook (Sakikkû)
Short Description: A 40-tablet Akkadian diagnostic manual used by exorcist-priests to interpret physical symptoms as divine or demonic signs. The text treats the body as a symbolic landscape, where illness is read like a script of cosmic disorder, it categorizes ailments to identify their supernatural origin and ritual resolution. The Sakikkû is a cornerstone of Mesopotamian ritual medicine.

Name: Kudurru Inscriptions (Boundary Stones)
Short Description: Kudurrus are stone monuments from Kassite Babylonia that served as public, permanent records of royal land grants. Each kudurru recorded a gift of land—often tax-exempt—bestowed by the king upon a noble, priest, or official, and was deposited in temples to ensure divine protection and posterity. The stones fused legal authority and divine oversight, featuring detailed inscriptions of the land boundaries and rights involved, followed by an array of divine symbols—emblems of the gods who served as cosmic guarantors of the decree.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Father Archetype, Terrible Father, Wise Old Man, Persona

Name: The Babylonian Theodicy
Short Description: A poetic dialogue between a suffering man and his friend, structured in a formal acrostic. The sufferer laments the injustice of the world: the wicked prosper, the innocent suffer, and the gods seem silent. His friend responds by defending divine justice, offering theological explanations and urging patience. The conversation ultimately ends without full resolution, capturing the tension between lived suffering and theological certainty.

Name: Mul.Apin (The Plough Star)
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: Babylonian astronomical compendium that systematizes the movements of stars, planets, and seasonal phenomena to guide agricultural timing, ritual observance, and calendrical precision. Its core function is to align human activity—especially harvesting—with the structured rhythms of the heavens.

Name: Dialogue of Pessimism
Short Description: A darkly ironic dialogue in which a master suggests various actions (eating, fighting, marrying, rebelling, etc.), and his servant praises each idea — only for the master to immediately reject it as meaningless. The cycle repeats until the master finally suggests killing the servant, leaving the ending ambiguous. The text deconstructs reason, ambition, and even morality, leaving only absurdity.

Name: Enūma Anu Enlil
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Logic / Formal Reasoning, Political Science / Law
Short Description: A monumental series of celestial omens, Enūma Anu Enlil offered interpretations of the stars, planets, and eclipses as messages from the gods. Used to guide decisions of war, succession, and ritual action, it framed the night sky as a divine script and positioned the priesthood as readers of fate. First compiled around 1800 BCE and standardized between c. 1100–600 BCE, it continued to be copied and reinterpreted well into the Hellenistic period. It remained the cornerstone of Mesopotamian imperial risk management—a system in which cosmic patterns dictated earthly power, binding the fates of kings and empires to the motions of the heavens.
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality, Divine Intervention, Initiation

Name: Šumma ālu (If a City is Situated on a Height)
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Logic / Formal Reasoning, Political Science / Law
Short Description: A vast Akkadian omen series composed in “if-then” format, used by priest-diviners to interpret signs from anomalies in nature, human behavior, and the built environment. First emerging in the Old Babylonian period, it was greatly expanded and standardized between c. 1100–600 BCE, and continued to be recopied and adapted into the Hellenistic era. It reflects a worldview in which the cosmos was seen as legible and intentional, and priestly authority rested on the ability to decode reality.
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Current Geographical Location: Northern Iraq and parts of Syria

Name: Assyrian Royal Inscriptions
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Dialectics (Conflict), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The inscriptions record the military campaigns, building projects, and divine legitimacy of Assyrian kings. Written in Akkadian cuneiform and carved into stone or clay, they portray the king as the chosen agent of the god Ashur, tasked with expanding order through warfare and punishing rebellion as sacrilege.

Name: Sargon Legend (Sargon Birth Legend)
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Subversion (Negation), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The legend retells the mythic origin of Sargon of Akkad, founder of the world’s first empire. Revived over a millennium after his reign, the story served as a template for later rulers—particularly in the Neo-Assyrian Empire, where kings often lacked strong dynastic legitimacy. The text provided a sacred precedent for outsider-usurpers, reframing humble origins as signs of divine election and destined rule.

Name: Bārûtu Series
Short Description: A vast Mesopotamian compendium of extispicy (liver divination), used primarily by priest-diviners (bārû) to interpret omens from the livers of sacrificial animals. It contains thousands of entries that systematically correlate specific liver anomalies with prophetic meanings—often concerning the king, warfare, or state affairs. These texts served as a predictive corpus for decision-making in political, military, and religious matters, embedding cosmic meaning in anatomical signs.
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Author: Esagil-kīn-apli

Name: Šurpu Series
Short Description: A multi-tablet Babylonian incantation and ritual text used in purification and exorcism ceremonies. Its central purpose is to rid a person of unknown sins or curses—especially those committed unknowingly—which were believed to cause illness, misfortune, or divine punishment. The text includes a systematic invocation of various gods, detailed confessions, and ritual instructions involving fire, water, and offerings. The name Šurpu means “burning,” and the ritual often culminates in symbolic destruction—such as the burning of effigies or cursed objects—to signify purification.
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Death, Rebirth, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Neo-Assyrian Letters
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Dialectics (Conflict), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Phenomenology (Experiential)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Political Science / Law, Warfare, History, Public Relations
Short Description: A vast collection of internal imperial correspondence written in Akkadian cuneiform during the reigns of kings like Esarhaddon and Ashurbanipal. Sent between the royal court and provincial governors, generals, priests, and scribes, they document military strategy, administrative updates, divination reports, and political control. These letters reflect a worldview of hierarchical order, divine kingship, and total imperial oversight.

Name: Fall of Nineveh Chronicle
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: This Babylonian chronicle records the destruction of Nineveh, capital of the Assyrian Empire, by a coalition of Babylonian, Median, and Scythian forces. Composed shortly after the event, it offers a terse, factual account of Assyria’s collapse—its king slain, its city burned, its empire ended. The text frames the rise of Babylon as the natural and inevitable new axis of order.

Name: Neo-Babylonian Laws
Short Description: A late Mesopotamian legal corpus from the Neo-Babylonian empire, continuing and adapting the tradition of earlier divine law codes. Though less theologically theatrical than Hammurabi’s, these laws reflect the priestly vision of sacred order through legal regularity, used to reinforce elite property rights, temple authority, and imperial legitimacy.
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Cylinder of Nabonidus
Short Description: A ritual inscription from Nabonidus, the last king of Babylon, detailing temple restorations and devotion to the moon god Sin. Composed during a period of political isolation and priestly alienation, the text serves less as a triumph and more as a desperate gesture of re-alignment with divine tradition. Written just before the Persian conquest of Babylon, it stands as a document of symbolic uncertainty—an attempt to recover lost legitimacy.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Persona, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype

Name: Egibi Family Archive
Short Description: A large corpus of clay tablets documenting the business activities of the Egibi family, a wealthy and influential banking and merchant dynasty. The tablets record loans, land leases, slave sales, tax payments, temple endowments, and legal disputes. The archive offers a rare window into the economic infrastructure, social hierarchies, and administrative sophistication of late Mesopotamian urban life, showing how elite families operated as key financial intermediaries during imperial transitions from Babylonian to Persian rule.

Name: Chronicle of Nabonidus
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Dialectics (Conflict), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: The text records key events from the reign of Nabonidus, focusing especially on his prolonged absence from the capital and his neglect of the Marduk cult. Composed shortly after his fall, likely under Persian authority, the chronicle subtly portrays Nabonidus as impious and unfit to rule—implicitly justifying the Persian conquest of Babylon under Cyrus the Great as a divinely sanctioned restoration of cosmic and cultic order.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Terrible Father, Wise Old Man

Name: Cyrus Cylinder
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: The Cyrus Cylinder is a royal inscription written in Akkadian cuneiform. It presents him as a divinely chosen ruler, elected by Marduk, the Babylonian god, to restore cosmic and social order after the impiety of Nabonidus, Babylon’s last king. Cyrus claims to have peacefully entered Babylon, restored temples, returned displaced peoples and sacred images, and reestablished local cults. It represents one of the earliest articulations of just, tolerant, and theologically-sanctioned empire, blending Babylonian symbolic structures with emerging Persian imperial ideology.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Persona, Hero, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype

Name: Nabonidus Inscriptions (in Aramaic)
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: Theocratic-royal texts written by the Neo-Babylonian king Nabonidus, inscribed on stone stelae and slabs, during his self-imposed exile in Tema. In them, Nabonidus recounts how the moon god Sin appeared to him in a dream and commanded him to build a temple. He justifies his ten-year absence from Babylon as a divine mission and asserts his legitimacy and piety, despite breaking with Babylonian religious orthodoxy by elevating Sin over Marduk. The inscriptions reflect a fusion of personal mysticism, royal propaganda, and theological reordering.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Wise Old Man, Terrible Father, Initiator
